author: By Simon Romero
title: Mexico’s President Bet Big on Oil. His Successor Will Be Stuck With the Tab.
description: Mexico’s next leader, Claudia Sheinbaum, is a climate scientist who has signaled a clean energy pivot. But a huge wager on fossil fuels by her political mentor stands in her way.
content: On a sweltering day in August, Claudia Sheinbaum appeared with her mentor, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, to inaugurate one of the costliest infrastructure projects in Mexico’s history: a $16 billion oil refinery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Teams Leave, but Oakland Still Finds Reasons to Cheer
description: The Raiders and the Warriors are gone and the A’s are leaving, but teams in lesser-known leagues are trying to fill the void and connect with the city.
content: On a cool May night, as the sun set over San Francisco in the distance, drummers and flag-waving fans led cheers of “Ohhhh-O-O-O Oakland” (to the tune of “Seven Nation Army” by the White Stripes) and “Let’s go, Oakland!” (clap clap, clap clap clap) as one of the city’s biggest sports teams pulled out a nail-biting victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: Liza Colón-Zayas’s Medallion
description: The heirloom, passed down by her grandmother, connects the Emmy-nominated actress to her Puerto Rican heritage.
content: Liza Colón-Zayas used to ride her bike between the living room and kitchen of her grandmother’s apartment in the Bronx. Her Puerto Rican grandmother didn’t speak English, and Ms. Colón-Zayas, a Bronx-native Nuyorican, didn’t speak Spanish. But the two found other ways to communicate: through her grandmother’s patience as she rode her two-wheeler around the tight space; through hand gestures and homemade Puerto Rican food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: Can Grunting During Exercise Give You an Edge?
description: Some people can’t help letting out a little noise during a hard workout. It might serve a purpose.
content: I recently went rock climbing in a serene park in southern Wyoming called Vedauwoo. The desert was tranquil in the early morning, a breeze gently moving through the trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Affectionate Way to Walk
description: Ryan McCarty’s Saturday puzzle takes us on an exhilarating path.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s been a little while since we’ve seen a Ryan McCarty crossword in The New York Times. This is his first grid of 2024, but he is a Saturday stalwart and a themeless king. After doing a nervous once-over, since Mr. McCarty’s puzzles are often tough to break into, I started from the very bottom and found success. The trivia, especially, seems easier as you move down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Hwaida Saad
title: In a Grim Palestinian Refugee Community, People See Hope in Hamas
description: In Ein al-Hilweh, Lebanon, long mired in poverty and despair, Hamas recruitment is up and the downtrodden air has given way to defiance and celebration.
content: Ein al-Hilweh, Lebanon’s largest community of Palestinian refugees and their descendants, has long been a downtrodden place, impoverished and racked by factional violence. Its residents usually have a grim view of their future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: ‘Run, Kamala, Run’: Mention of Harris’s Father Was a Rare Homage to a Fleeting Figure
description: In her convention speech, Kamala Harris told of being inspired by her father, a prominent economist who was otherwise largely a footnote in her personal story.
content: “Run, Kamala, run.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Passarella
title: How to Soothe an Itchy Bug Bite
description: There are a number of ways to stop scratching, from medicines to mental tricks.
content: I’m one of the unfortunate souls who, for reasons still only loosely explained by science, seems to taste delicious to mosquitoes. So was my father, who taught me as a child that the best way to stop the itch was to press an “x” into the middle of the bite with my fingernail. It hurt a little bit, but that was the point: The pain made me forget about the itch, at least temporarily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Youmi Kim and Jun Michael Park
title: The DMZ Is an Unhealed Wound for Korea. It’s Also a Source of Great Honey.
description: The heavily fortified area separating North and South Korea is home to a biodiverse landscape and is a place of deep meaning for nearby farmers whose bees can fly freely through it.
content: Cho Seong-hoan’s father liked to say that the honeybees on his farm were lucky. Unlike typical South Koreans, they could cross into North Korea, as he had done before war divided the peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Hettie Jones, Poet and Author Who Nurtured the Beats, Dies at 90
description: She and her husband, LeRoi Jones, published works by their literary friends. After he left her and became Amiri Baraka, she found her own voice.
content: Hettie Jones, a poet and author who with her husband, LeRoi Jones (who later became the incendiary poet and playwright Amiri Baraka), made her household a hub for Beat writers and other artists — but who was often described as a footnote in the rise of her famous spouse as “the white wife” he disavowed — died on Aug. 13 in Philadelphia. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Plan Beats No Plan
description: The candidates’ housing plans offer a window on how they would govern.
content: This isn’t a policy election. There’s no defining issue like tax cuts in 2000 or health care in 2008 or trade in 2016. Democrats are focused on convincing voters that Donald Trump poses an existential threat to the American way of life, and vice versa. But policy remains the purpose of politics, and the choice of a president is also the choice of a housing policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Busload of Indian Tourists in Nepal Plunges Into River, Killing at Least 27
description: Nepal, a poor and mountainous country, has long struggled with road safety.
content: At least 27 people died in Nepal on Friday when a tour bus fell into a gorge and went into the Marsyangdi River in the central district of Tanahun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Do I Really Need a Real Estate Agent?
description: Under new rules, potential buyers may now be responsible for paying their agent’s commission. Some now question the need for that agent.
content: Less than two months ago, Joanne Y. Cleaver sold her home in a suburb of Charlotte for $725,000 in an unusual way: Facebook Marketplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Ronda Rousey Apologizes for Reposting Sandy Hook Conspiracy Video
description: The former U.F.C. star apologized after Reddit users asked her about the video she shared 11 years ago. She called it “the single most regrettable decision of my life.”
content: The former mixed martial arts superstar and professional wrestler Ronda Rousey apologized on Friday for reposting a video in 2013 that spread conspiracy theories about the Sandy Hook Elementary School mass shooting, calling it “the single most regrettable decision of my life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kiuko Notoya and River Akira Davis
title: Why 7-Eleven Is a National Treasure in Japan
description: Convenience stores are a part of the country’s culture, meaning that the foreign buyout bid for 7-Eleven, the largest chain, could be a hard sell in Japan.
content: In Japan, convenience stores are celebrated. Clean and bright, they are stocked with fresh and affordable lunchboxes, steamed buns and stews in the winter. The celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain once called them “the one vice” he couldn’t give up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: New Training and Tougher Rules: How Colleges Are Trying to Tame Gaza Protests
description: University officials are spelling out strict codes around protests. They say they are trying to be clear. Others say they are trying to suppress speech.
content: Less than 10 minutes had passed before Daniel Diermeier, Vanderbilt University’s chancellor, told hundreds of new students what the school would not do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: Biden’s Asylum Restrictions Are Working as Predicted, and as Warned
description: Border numbers are down significantly. But migrant activists say the restrictions President Biden imposed in June are weeding out people who may have legitimate claims of asylum.
content: In the months since President Biden imposed sweeping restrictions on asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border, the policy appears to be working exactly as he hoped and his critics feared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: With Freight Off the Rails, Rare Open Tracks for Passenger Trains
description: The brief lockout of freight railway workers gave Via Rail Canada trains a temporary reprieve from their second-class status.
content: If anyone benefited from the short lockout at the Canadian National and Canadian Pacific Kansas City railways this week, it might have been passengers on most Via Rail Canada trains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: In Critical Border District, Republican Pairs Immigrant Story With Tough Stance
description: Representative Juan Ciscomani is seeking a second term by promoting his immigrant biography, but his record in Congress could alienate voters in his Arizona district bordering Mexico.
content: When Representative Juan Ciscomani appeared onstage at a community center filled with banquet tables in Tucson recently to speak to high school seniors from underserved communities, he recounted his personal story of immigrating from Mexico as a young child, helping to support his family and eventually making it to Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Kate LoPresti, Wendy Dorr, Diane Wong and Alex Marshall
title: The Hunt for the Next ‘Baby Reindeer’
description: Inside the Edinburgh Festival Fringe
content: Every August, visitors from around the world journey to Scotland to attend one of the world’s biggest theater celebrations, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. It is known for cutting-edge shows and a carnival-like atmosphere, and as the place where hit shows like “Fleabag,” “Baby Reindeer” and “Six” got their start. The Times’s European culture reporter, Alex Marshall, went to the festival to find out what makes a Fringe show a hit, and what’s landing with audiences this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Kortava
title: Sometimes Protest Movements Are a Slow, Slow Burn
description: In “To the Success of Our Hopeless Cause,” Benjamin Nathans takes stock of the generation of dissidents who helped loosen the bonds of tyranny in the Soviet Union.
content: It is widely held that the beginning of the end of Soviet totalitarianism arrived in the 1980s, when the general secretary Mikhail Gorbachev ushered in a period of democratic reform. Under his policies of perestroika (restructuring) and glasnost (openness), the state relaxed censorship laws, brought private enterprise further out of the shadows and stood back as one Soviet satellite after another — Poland, Czechoslovakia, Romania and others — slipped out of Moscow’s orbit. Hundreds of political prisoners returned home and hundreds of thousands, including members of my family, were exonerated for political offenses committed during the reign of Joseph Stalin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: This Roasted Dill Salmon Is a Thing of Beauty
description: “I have made this numerous times, and it is one of my favorite recipes,” one reader said.
content: Is there anything more beautiful than a serving-platter-size piece of perfectly roasted salmon? (Well, sure: a tropical sunset, a $10 bill lying on the sidewalk, my dog.) A heavy fillet of salmon, its fattiness made more unctuous with olive oil and its brininess brightened with citrus and herbs — if that’s on the table, the little “Oh boy oh boy” part of my brain lights up, and I am instantly hungry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Many Gen Z Men Feel Left Behind. Some See Trump as an Answer.
description: Men under 30 are much more likely to support Donald Trump than women their age. It’s a far bigger gender gap than in older generations.
content: In some ways, this presidential election has become a referendum on gender roles — and the generation with the biggest difference in opinion between male and female voters is Generation Z.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and John Yoon
title: New Arrest Made in Knife Attack That Left 3 Dead in Germany
description: The authorities announced the end of a manhunt, nearly a day after the attack, which happened Friday night at a festival in the city of Solingen.
content: The German police late Saturday made a third arrest in the fatal knife attack that took place Friday at a street festival in the western city of Solingen. An official said they had ended the search for a suspect in the stabbing episode, which killed three and injured several more, some of them seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Not Only for Killing: Drones Are Now Detecting Land Mines in Ukraine
description: Ukraine is a beta test for embedding artificial intelligence and other new technologies in drones and robots to find deadly land mines, saving lives and allowing military forces to advance more quickly.
content: With a stiff gait, a drone dog stomped up and down a makeshift minefield at a U.S. Army testing center in Virginia, shuddering when it neared a plate-size puck meant to simulate an anti-tank explosive. On its back was a stack of cameras, GPS devices, radios and thermal imaging technology that military developers hope will help it detect mines at close range, sparing humans from that dangerous task.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Can the G.O.P. Really Become the Party of Workers?
description: A new generation of Republicans is learning to love labor. It’s not clear if labor will love them back.
content: The most surprising moment of this year’s Republican National Convention may have come on its first night, when the president of the Teamsters railed in prime time against corporate elites and denounced a “war against labor” by business groups. The gasps from some in the hall were almost audible on television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight and Kate Conger
title: Elon Musk’s X Is Leaving San Francisco. City Officials Say ‘Good Riddance.’
description: The company, founded in the city as Twitter, is moving its headquarters to Texas as a shadow of its former self.
content: San Francisco’s long relationship with X is nearly over — and city officials are far from heartbroken.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should We Be Worried About Population Decline?
description: Readers discuss a guest essay that argued that we should be.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 441
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Aug. 25, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: These Young Women Didn’t Want to Vote for Biden. They’re All In on Harris.
description: In new polls, a large majority of young women plan to vote for the vice president. We talked with eight of them.
content: Constance Lancelle, 22, of Milwaukee, was “definitely not interested in voting for Biden,” she said. But with Kamala Harris as the Democratic presidential candidate, she said, “I feel like politics have been a dream.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Manners
title: Yes, You Can Plan a Stress-Free Wedding
description: Many couples are incorporating the quiet life trend into their nuptials, avoiding a big, traditional celebration in favor of a smaller, more relaxed gathering.
content: Melanie Neff Díaz and Silvino Edward Díaz Burns wanted to avoid the stress of a large, traditional wedding, so they hosted a quiet celebration at a local restaurant for their nuptials on June 23.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Kate Conger
title: How Elon Musk Got Tangled Up in Blue
description: Twitter Blue, a revamped subscription service that let users buy verified badges, was the first big test for the platform’s new owner. It didn’t go well.
content: By Nov. 9, 2022, anxiety was high among the Twitter employees gathered at the company’s San Francisco headquarters. They had spent part of that morning trying to gently explain to their new boss, Elon Musk, that the service they had just launched was dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Why Harris’s Barrier-Breaking Bid Feels Nothing Like Hillary Clinton’s
description: The first-female-president energy of 2016 has been replaced by a more serious tone, with Democrats warning gravely of the new frontiers in the post-Roe era.
content: They still wear suffragist-white outfits and cheer on the prospect of “Madam President.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Republicans Are Right: One Party Is ‘Anti-Family and Anti-Kid’
description: When right-wingers pursue policies that mire children in poverty, it takes gall to preen about their family values.
content: In attacking Democrats and Kamala Harris, Republicans have been making a legitimate point: One of our major political parties has worked to undermine America’s families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Explosions Outside a France Synagogue Were a Terrorist Attack, Prosecutors Say
description: Politicians quickly condemned the attack, at a time when antisemitic incidents have been on the rise in France. A suspect has been arrested in the case.
content: Two vehicles parked outside a synagogue exploded in a French town on Saturday in what prosecutors called an act of terrorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Ruhling
title: How a Children’s Museum Director Spends Her Sundays
description: Kate Mirand Calleri, the director of education at the Brooklyn Children’s Museum, braves tarantulas and crowded subways before relaxing with “Antiques Roadshow.”
content: Working at the Brooklyn Children’s Museum is, happily, child’s play for Kate Mirand Calleri.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Tom Brown Jr., World-Renowned Survivalist, Is Dead at 74
description: For decades, he ran a school in the New Jersey wilderness that taught thousands of students how to survive and even thrive in the great outdoors.
content: Tom Brown Jr., who was considered the country’s foremost authority on wilderness survival, and who taught thousands of people how to track deer, fletch arrows, forage for food and generally thrive in the great outdoors, died on Aug. 16 in Neptune, N.J. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton L. Delgado
title: For Young Cambodians, a Mobile History Lesson From a Dark Time
description: Most people in Cambodia are under 30, born long after the horrific rule of the Khmer Rouge. A bus is touring the country to make sure it’s not forgotten.
content: The brand-new bus gleamed as it weaved through rush-hour traffic in Cambodia’s capital. It was headed to a school, bearing a lesson about the country’s darkest period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Ben Casselman
title: Care Policies Take Center Stage in Harris’s Economic Message
description: The Democratic nominee says she wants to make raising a family more affordable. But she has provided few details on her proposals.
content: The “care economy” — a broad set of policies aimed at helping parents and other caregivers — was the great unfinished work of President Biden’s domestic agenda. Vice President Kamala Harris has made it a central aspect of her campaign to succeed him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 24, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 24, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about the unearthing of the second-largest diamond ever found misstated the weight of the diamond in pounds. It weighs a little more than a pound, not more than a pound and a half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Edelman
title: My Play Went to Broadway. Then a Death Changed Everything.
description: When my friend and collaborator died before our comedy show opened on Broadway, I mourned him from the stage.
content: Imagine: You make something with someone you love. It’s a thing that’s tangible but needs participation, like a watch that requires winding. Now imagine that person goes away, and you still have to tend the garden you planted with him, or sing the song you wrote together or walk through a house that is now fully characterized by its emptiness. Many people, I know, don’t have to imagine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: An Early, Original Print by W. Eugene Smith
description: W. Eugene Smith was known for his war photography. But a photo he took of a trough as a teenager in Wichita, Kan., helped kick-start his career.
content: The American photojournalist W. Eugene Smith (1918-1978) is renowned for his war photography, including images he captured in the Pacific theater during World War II, and for his gripping photo essays, a form he helped popularize while working for Life magazine in the 1940s. His final photo essay, “Minamata: A Warning to the World,” which first appeared in Life in 1972 and later became a book, brought global attention to victims of industrial mercury poisoning in Minamata, a Japanese fishing village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Aaron Boxerman
title: Hamas Agrees to Meet With Mediators in Cairo Ahead of Cease-Fire Talks
description: Fighting has raged in Gaza even as the United States, Qatar and Egypt have pushed for a deal, with Israeli strikes overnight killing dozens, according to health officials in Gaza.
content: Hamas representatives were heading to Cairo on Saturday to meet with mediators before a new round of Gaza cease-fire talks as the United States, Qatar and Egypt push to reach an agreement they hope can stave off the growing threat of regional war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: The Loch Ness Monster Has Company in the Neighborhood: Wild Boars
description: Local residents say the animals are roaming the roads and hills around the lake, tearing up lawns and terrorizing sheep.
content: “Heaven” is how Peter Jamieson describes his home in Scotland, with its uninterrupted view of Loch Ness and the green hills stretching beyond, seemingly forever. But there is a problem in paradise, and it has nothing to do with the mythical aquatic monster that brought fame to the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Bad Decisions and Second Chances That Lead to Love: 4 New Romance Novels
description: Our columnist reviews books by Danica Nava, Courtney Milan, Zen Cho and Karelia and Fay Stetz-Waters.
content: Romance loves to build triumphant outcomes out of terrible decisions. And Danica Nava’s contemporary THE TRUTH ACCORDING TO EMBER (Berkley, paperback, $16.99) stars a heroine who makes more bad decisions than most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Iowa Man Helped Distribute ‘Sadistic’ Videos Showing Torture of Monkeys, U.S. Says
description: Philip Colt Moss, 41, paid another man for videos of monkeys being sexually abused, tortured and killed, prosecutors said. A child in Indonesia made the videos, according to a previous indictment.
content: An Iowa man was arrested this month for his role in a group that created and shared so-called animal crush videos in which monkeys were brutally tortured, sexually abused and killed in sadistic ways, federal prosecutors said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,163
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 25, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Is Huge. These Books Help Cut It Down to Size.
description: Dear readers,
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Extends Boeing Starliner Astronauts’ Space Station Stay to 2025
description: Persistent concerns with the vehicle’s propulsion systems mean Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore will return home next year in a SpaceX vehicle.
content: Two astronauts who have spent months aboard the International Space Station will have to stay there months longer after NASA decided on Saturday that they could not return on Boeing’s troubled Starliner space vehicle. They will return instead on a SpaceX capsule next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Diamond
title: Overlooked No More: Mabel Addis, Who Pioneered Storytelling in Video Gaming
description: She was a teacher when she participated in an educational experiment with IBM. As a result, she became the first female video game designer.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Fire Destroys Grandstand From ‘A League of Their Own’
description: The field and wooden grandstand in Ontario, Calif., were the backdrop for the 1992 movie about a women’s baseball league.
content: The wooden grandstand, locker rooms, press box and dugout of Jay Littleton Ball Park, a baseball field in California that was featured in the 1992 movie “A League of Their Own,” were destroyed in a fire on Thursday, a city spokesman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: Childhood Stardom Is Rough. Jenna Ortega Is Still Recovering.
description: The actress talks about learning to protect herself and the hard lessons of early fame.
content: If you have a tween daughter, as I do, you know that Jenna Ortega is a big deal. In 2022, Ortega starred as the title character in Netflix’s “Addams Family” reboot, “Wednesday,” and quickly became beloved by viewers for her character’s snarky, dark and brutally honest personality. The show was a hit, and suddenly Wednesday — and by extension Ortega — were everywhere: on merch, on the streets for Halloween and all over the internet doing her meme-able dance moves. It was the kind of star-making, culture-saturating role that is life-changing for a young actor. It was also, as Ortega told me over the course of our two conversations, completely disorienting to become so famous so fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Toni Braxton, Whoopi Goldberg Fan, Watches ‘The View’ in Her Pajamas
description: “I love a good debate,” said the R&B singer and actress, who can be seen alongside her sisters in the TV series “The Braxtons.” “It doesn’t always make you smile, but it always provokes thought.”
content: Toni Braxton wasn’t initially enthusiastic about rebooting “Braxton Family Values,” the reality show in which she starred for seven seasons with her sisters, Traci, Towanda, Trina and Tamar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: On Ukraine’s Independence Day, Zelensky Celebrates Push Into Russia
description: Although the cross-border offensive carries risks, it also paid dividends on Saturday with the first prisoner swap with Russia in several months.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky, always adept at messaging, used his latest Independence Day speech on Saturday to drive home the idea that Ukraine is taking the fight to Russia, even as his troops struggle along the front line in the east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Ken Belson
title: The N.F.L. May Soon Welcome a New Kind of Owner
description: At a meeting next week, team owners are expected to approve rules that would allow private equity firms to invest in their franchises.
content: For more than a century, National Football League owners have been an exclusive club. With rules that place tough restrictions on who is allowed to buy teams — and how those purchases can be financed — only the extremely wealthy can afford to join. Now they’re on the cusp of admitting a new kind of member.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Italian Authorities Open Manslaughter Investigation in Yacht Disaster
description: A prosecutor involved in the inquiry into the sinking said it was “plausible” that crimes were committed during the accident.
content: Italian authorities said on Saturday that they had opened a manslaughter investigation into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht, but that they had not yet zeroed in on any potential suspects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Daffy Donald, Turning Pea Green With Envy
description: Trump, who usually keeps others off-balance, is unbalanced by Kamala.
content: I have a crow in my backyard in D.C. that has been cawing for three weeks. It has been driving me crazy, so I was happy to get out of town and back on the trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tahmima Anam
title: An Old Bangladeshi Reflex Threatens Its Revolution
description: My country must break the cycle of denial and revenge that has divided and held it back for decades.
content: In Bangladesh, we are experts at erasing history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig, Libby Leonard and Lisa L. Schell
title: In Hawaii, a Sense of Alertness Without Panic Ahead of Tropical Storm Hone
description: Although the storm is not expected to pass directly over the Big Island, forecasters warned of threats including flooding and damaging winds.
content: Debbie Arita, an office manager at a supermarket in Hilo on the Big Island of Hawaii, took stock of the conditions. Tropical Storm Hone was approaching the region, but the scene on Friday was far from chaotic — no frantic rush for supplies, no desperate boarding up of windows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: After a Big Week for Democrats, One Good Day for Trump
description: Former President Donald J. Trump talked policy in Las Vegas and seemed almost chipper. In Arizona, he reveled in the endorsement of a former campaign rival, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
content: It was a moment the political world had been wondering about for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: How Media Outlets on the Right and Left Covered Kennedy’s Trump Endorsement
description: Conservative coverage of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s decision to suspend his presidential campaign focused on the potential boon for the former president. Liberal outlets downplayed the impact it would have.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s decision to suspend his presidential campaign and endorse former President Donald J. Trump was — depending on where on the political spectrum the coverage came from — treated with either outright glee — or derision. Conservative sites primarily focused on the potential electoral boon to Mr. Trump, while liberal media outlets focused more on Mr. Kennedy’s dysfunctional campaign, including by returning to several negative story lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Simon J. Levien
title: After Kennedy’s Endorsement of Trump, the Two Signal a New Alliance
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who suspended his independent presidential bid earlier on Friday, was embraced by Donald J. Trump at a rally in Arizona. But the union’s political impact remains unclear.
content: One of the most attention-grabbing days of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s independent presidential bid was also its last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: Ancient Tablets Foretold Doom Awaiting Babylonian Kings
description: A new translation of cuneiform relics from the second millennium B.C. highlights the warnings that astrologers saw in eclipses.
content: It was good to be the king in ancient Babylonia, unless, of course, an eclipse occurred during his reign. Such an event foretold revolt, rebellion, defeat in war, loss of territory, plague, drought, crop failure, locust attacks or even the king’s death. Should the last omen be foretold, the king would go into hiding and a substitute — say, a prisoner or a simpleton — would be installed until the danger had passed. To appease the gods, someone would have to die, so upon the return of the true king, the substitute would be executed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Can Building Staff Enter My Rent-Stabilized Apartment Without Permission?
description: No, with some exceptions. But different rules may apply to a market-rate rental right down the hall.
content: Q: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan in a building made up of mostly market-rate units. The building staff are known to access apartments without notifying the tenant and without an apparent reason, such as a service ticket or an emergency issue. If I learn that the staff has entered my apartment without notice, what are my rights? What should I do if the building management does not address this?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Philosopher President, Near His End, on How to Be Truly Free
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 24, 2024.
content: “We have a house for the president. It’s four stories. To have tea you have to walk three blocks. Useless. They should make it a high school.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Morris and Kieran Dodds
title: How to Survive (and Maybe Conquer) the Edinburgh Fringe Festival
description: It’s a prime opportunity for performers looking to make a splash. Nadia Quinn, a comic actress and singer from New York, decided to give it a shot.
content: Nadia Quinn had been warned about bringing her show of wacky comic songs to the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh. Facebook groups, Reddit posts and friends suggested that taking on the 77-year-old festival as an unestablished performer was too daunting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh E. Katz and Melissa Guerrero
title: Pack Lunch, Drop Kids Off, Skate,Work
description: These moms have found a community while picking up the sport, falls and all.
content: On a chilly, windy morning in March, Nagisa Landfield’s and Leila Noelliste’s skateboard wheels boomed in unison with the clanking of construction work and semi trucks echoing nearby at a skatepark under the Kosciuszko Bridge in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Is There an Echo in Here?
description: Hear that? It’s John Kugelman, with a clamorous Sunday puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Michael Gold
title: Trump’s Carefully Scripted Week Kept Veering Off Script
description: Despite calls by his advisers to focus on the issues, former President Donald J. Trump has made it clear that he intends to keep running his campaign his way.
content: Donald J. Trump’s political endurance this year has been attributed in part to voters’ faded memories about why they denied him a second term four years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: The Hottest Commodity at the U.S. Open? Shade.
description: The tennis tournament, like the rest of New York City, is adapting to climate change.
content: As New York City contends with rising heat and unpredictable storms because of climate change, so does its marquee tennis tournament, the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Benjamin Mullin and Ken Belson
title: Who Is Edgar Bronfman Jr., Paramount’s 11th-Hour Suitor?
description: His bid to buy Paramount pits one son of a billionaire against the son of another.
content: When the media executive Edgar Bronfman Jr. submitted his last-ditch bid on Monday to take control of Paramount, his approach was greeted with surprise and skepticism. Who would take his unconventional coalition of investors seriously, especially when an $8 billion deal with Skydance was on the table?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: A French Museum Has Global Needs (but It Can’t Have New Jersey)
description: The Pompidou Center is creating international outposts to help fund a renovation of its Paris home. What happens now that Jersey City has pulled out?
content: The century-old Pathside Building in downtown Jersey City was originally a transportation hub for streetcar lines, but it took on a new role three years ago: It became the chosen destination for an outpost of the Pompidou Center, the Paris arts complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Out of Season
description: Summer’s coming to a close soon. You’re still, to some extent, in control of how you spend the time.
content: You are going to encounter people this weekend who will tell you that there’s one week left of summer. You don’t have to believe them. You don’t have to be one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum
title: Words Used at the Democratic and Republican National Conventions
description: Counting frequently spoken words and phrases at both events.
content: Counting frequently spoken words and phrases at both events.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Authorities Open Manslaughter Investigation in Italy Yacht Disaster
description: An Italian prosecutor in charge of the case said it was just the “initial phases” of the inquiry into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht where seven were killed.
content: An Italian prosecutor in charge of the case said it was just the “initial phases” of the inquiry into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht where seven were killed.
source.name: The New York Times
